titlestmt.titleproper: Metcalf Hall Protest Posters and Resident Life RecordsUA249

publicationstmt.publisher: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-10 19:15:12 -0400.

repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: Metcalf Hall Protest Posters and Resident Life Records
did.abstract: This collection contains protest posters and resident life records from Metcalf Hall.
did.langmaterial: This collection is mostly in English with some materials in Spanish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred by Vikram Krishnamakari and Chloe Amouyal, residents of Metcalf Hall, 2018, accession UA-2018-054.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in two series: Protest posters, and Resident Life records.

bioghist.head: Metcalf Hall
bioghist.p: Metcalf Hall was constructed in 1893 to serve as a dormitory for women students. It was named for Albert Metcalf, member of the Board of Trustees, who donated funds to construct the building. It was designed by J. Philip Rinn.

The building included a dining hall for women, and was supervised by a house matron. Residents were allowed to receive guests only in common area, and were required to be in their rooms by 10:00 p.m. nightly. The men students quickly dubbed the new residence the "Bird Cage" in honor of its residents.
In 1937 an addition to the west side of the building was made to provide additional housing for women, and nearly doubled the size of the original building.

Currently the building is home to the Metcalf Living and Learning Community, which is supervised by a scholar-in-residence who works with undergraduate students interested in current affairs in politics, education, and ethics and provides opportunities for students to engage Tufts' faculty and each other in a more informal atmosphere.

bioghist.head: Student Protests at Tufts, 1960s-1970s
bioghist.p: Tufts has a long history of student activism stemming from its founding, but one of the most acute periods of activism ran from 1967 to 1972. Opposition to the Vietnam War and was the biggest catalyst for student protest, but students also protested U.S. involvement in apartheid South Africa, for increased representation of and support for African-Americans on campus, and for greater student involvement in the Tufts administration. Opposition to the Vietnam War also prompted student protests against military recruitment and against the presence of the ROTC on campus.

In the fall of 1969, students organized a one-day boycott of classes in opposition to the Vietnam War. There were six major confrontations between the school and student protesters during the 1970-71 academic year. At the Fletcher School, the office of Dean Gullion was firebombed in March 1971 in an apparent act of opposition to his open support for the war and the School's close ties to the military, which had both been a frequent source of criticism from Tufts activists.
Student activism began to decline after the 1971-72 academic year, as the U.S.'s involvement in the Vietnam War drew to a close. Student activism on other issues has continued up to the present.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: These materials were discovered in a storage closet at Metcalf Hall by First Year Advisor Vikram Krishnamakari and resident Chloe Amouyal, who then contacted DCA. They were retrieved by Collections Management Archivist Adrienne Pruitt, Archives and Research Assistant Rose Koven, and Public Services and Outreach Archivist Pam Hopkins in April 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Metcalf Hall Protest Posters and Resident Life Records, 1969-1976. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing was completed by Leah Edelman and Alejandra Garcia in 2018. Materials were placed in archival boxes and folders where needed, and posters were arranged alphabetically by title. An item-level inventory and series-level descriptions were created, and the finding aid was created at the time of processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains protest posters addressing a variety of topics such as the Vietnam War, nuclear weapons, capitalism, and workers' rights; three checkout binders for residence halls at Tufts University; and a silkscreen for an original student musical that was found with the posters.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by poster title, followed by the silkscreen.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains protest posters addressing a variety of topics such as the Vietnam War, nuclear weapons, capitalism, and workers' rights. It includes several posters related to Kent State which likely date from spring and summer 1970. It also contains an undated silkscreen advertising an original musical, "Hasty Prophets," found with the protest posters in Metcalf Hall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed in a variety of colors: "All Free Peoples / University / Power to the People," with a figure of a person in the background.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of a crowd surrounding a dead man. There is a cartoon of a pig in the corner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quote by Rene Crevel, text in red.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text in yellow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of a black panther wrapped in barbed wire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reprint of the front page of the "Boston Herald." The main story is about the Kent State shootings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts a man in striped pajamas, a scene from Charlie Chaplin's 1917 film, "The Adventurer." Below the image is the following text: "Cambodia too?"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poster for events on May 15-17, 1970 at Tufts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quote by Eve Merriam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text in red.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reprint of an interview with former President Richard Nixon in which he explained why he would not be running for another term. The Vietnam War is featured prominently in the article.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small blue picture of what appears to be a hybrid of a military tank and the United States Capitol building.

did.unittitle: Hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Red monkeys covering themselves with the American flag.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Political cartoon of President Richard Nixon offering a second cigar with the word "Cambodia" written on it to a man. The man's first cigar--entitled "Vietnam"--has just exploded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The word "Strike" is written in Spanish and appears below a red power fist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of two elderly people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cover of "Time" magazine of President Richard Nixon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quote written in black with a red lightning bolt in the background.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Political cartoon of President Richard Nixon riding a tank. Below the cartoon is a brief statement about the cost of the Vietnam War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A red Statue of Liberty with a raised fist. Underneath the statue is the word "Strike".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The word "Love", where the middle two letters have been replaced with a fist and a peace sign. Text written in red.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Black and red image of two men, one of whom appears to be in pain. Text in the bottom right-hand corner of the image reads: "May 70 A. Smals".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Multicolored image of men wearing masks and playing the drums. Text in the bottom right-hand corner of the image reads: "May 70 A. Smals".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts a raised fist emerging out of urban homes and buildings. The text reads: "More / Housing / ? / Tax / the / Slumlords". The bottom right hand corner of the poster reads "ABCTU".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Purple picture of a militant woman holding a gun and a baby. Below the image is the following text: "Bring our sons home now."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quote by Ernest Hemingway above a picture of a cemetery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An armed and armored skeleton that is standing in front of the Earth and is flanked by gargoyles. The skeleton's shield is decorated with a swastika.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Red and white image of three men--two of whom are wearing military clothing and one of whom is wearing a mortarboard--forming a line and kissing each other's bottom. The first in line is kissing money offered by an outstretched hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pictures of two victims of the Kent State Shootings--Allison Krause and Sandra Lee Scheuer--above Carl Sandburg's poem, "Grass". Printed in red.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A red raised fist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Picture of a couple holding an American flag and standing in front of a car.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A row of tanks and soldiers in riot gear; above them is Uncle Sam, making two V symbol gestures. To the right of the tanks, soldiers, and Uncle Sam, is a quote by Adolf Hitler about strikes, danger, and law and order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advertises a strike at Harvard Stadium on May 30, in protest of the Vietnam War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Red lettering and picture of a dead man laying on the ground in a pool of blood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Picture of United States Representative H. James Shea Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Skeleton wearing a service ribbon and saluting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A red raised fist in front of a star-less and stripe-less United States flag. The corner of the flag references Kent State University and text in the middle of the flag reads: "Stars and Strikes?".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of a factory producing missiles.

did.unittitle: Strange fruit is hard to swallow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts the lynching of Abram Smith and Thomas Shipp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A red raised fist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The words "Support / The / Strike" appear above a red raised fist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts a teacher's swivel chair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts a hand holding an olive branch. Text on the sleeve of the hand reads "The strike / Is For / Everyone," and text adjacent to the hand reads "Join / The / Strike / For / Peace".

did.unittitle: There is some shit we will not eat strike

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Taking the format of a newspaper, this item describes strikes against the Vietnam War from around the country.

did.unittitle: Things don't necessarily go better with coke..

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poster has two statements: "Things Don't Necessarily / Go Better with Coke.." and "Don't drink Coke / Support the National Economic Boycott".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poster depicts hooded figures. Below the figures is the following text: "This War / Destroys / Families." Some of the posters have text written in Spanish.

did.unittitle: Esta guerra destruye a las familias

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poster depicts hooded figures. Below the figures is the following text: "This War / Destroys / Families." Some of the posters have text written in Spanish. This is a scan of one of nine duplicate posters in the folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poster depicts hooded figures. Below the figures is the following text: "This War / Destroys / Families." Some of the posters have text written in Spanish. This is a scan of one of nine duplicate posters in the folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts an image from the Kent State shootings.

did.unittitle: War for us has been a sport

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two blue and white images of a dead child. Behind the child are bombers in flight.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts a raised fist emerging out of urban homes and buildings. The text reads "We / Demand / Maintenance / No Eviction / No / Luxury Apts". The bottom right hand corner of the poster reads "ABCTU".

did.unittitle: When dissent turns to violence it invites tragedy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Depicts images of President Richard Nixon, the four victims of the Kent State Shootings--Allison Krause, Jeffrey Glen Miller, Sandra Lee Scheuer, and William Knox Schroeder--and several quotes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A ballot with one question: "Do you favor the immediate withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam?"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A female/Venus symbol that has been combined with a raised fist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The poster's text reads: "World War III is unique because it will never be mentioned in history books".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Image of a dove holding an olive branch. The poster reads: "Write to Congress / It Helps".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Undated silk screen advertising an original musical, "Hasty Prophets."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains checkout binders for three residence halls at Tufts University.
